context:
The ultra high risk (UHR) for psychosis criteria have been validated in a number of studies. However, it is not known whether particular UHR criteria (Attenuated Psychotic Symptoms (APS), Brief Limited Intermittent Psychotic Symptoms (BLIPS) or Trait vulnerability criteria), or combination of criteria, is associated with a higher risk of transition to psychosis. The current study investigated this issue over a 6-month follow-up period. We hypothesised that the risk of transition would increase in the following order: Trait alone<APS alone<APS+Trait<BLIPS.

Data on UHR intake criteria and transition to psychosis status at 6 months were analysed for UHR patients seen at the PACE clinic, Orygen Youth Health between January 2000 and November 2008.

A total of 928 new referrals were accepted into the PACE clinic over this period of whom 817 (88%) had baseline information available for analysis. The percentage of subjects who presented with APS, Trait and BLIPS were 83%, 27% and 4%, respectively. When the two intermediate groups (APS alone and APS+Trait) were combined, there was evidence that the risk of transition increased in the order of Trait alone<APS<BLIPS (p=0.024, adjusted analysis).
topic: Propose how the study’s findings could inform differential preventive interventions or monitoring protocols tailored to each UHR subcategory.
question: A clinic has limited resources and seeks to allocate preventive interventions and monitoring intensity based on the reported 6‑month transition risks (Trait alone < APS < BLIPS). Which of the following tiered protocols best aligns with these findings?

choices.A: Monthly psychoeducational check‑ins for all UHR individuals, regardless of subgroup, supplemented by quarterly clinician review.
choices.B: Quarterly remote check‑ins and basic stress management for Trait alone; biweekly cognitive‑behavioral therapy and monthly family involvement for APS; weekly psychiatric evaluations with low‑dose antipsychotic consideration and crisis planning for BLIPS.
choices.C: Immediate initiation of low‑dose antipsychotics for Trait alone; monthly group therapy for APS; the same biweekly cognitive‑behavioral therapy for BLIPS as for APS.
choices.D: Weekly in‑person psychotherapy for Trait alone; quarterly medication review for APS; annual psychiatric follow‑up for BLIPS.

explanation: Protocol B proportionally increases intervention intensity in line with the risk gradient—minimal yet regular support for Trait alone, moderate psychotherapy for APS, and intensive monitoring plus pharmacological consideration for BLIPS.

context:
The purpose of this study is to evaluate right ventricular (RV) volume and function after pulmonary valve replacement (PVR) and to address the issue of optimal surgical timing in these patients.

Chronic pulmonary regurgitation (PR) following repair of tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) leads to RV dilation and an increased incidence of sudden cardiac death in adult patients.

We studied 25 consecutive adult patients who underwent PVR for significant PR late after repair of TOF. Radionuclide angiography was performed in all at a mean of 8.2 months (+/- 8 months) before PVR and repeated at a mean of 28.0 months (+/- 22.8 months) after the operation. Right ventricular (RV) end-systolic volume (RVESV), RV end-diastolic volume (RVEDV) and RV ejection fraction (RVEF) were measured.

Mean RVEDV, RVESV and RVEF remained unchanged after PVR (227.1 ml versus 214.9 ml, p = 0.74; 157.4 ml versus 155.4 ml, p = 0.94; 35.6% versus 34.7%, p = 0.78, respectively). Of the 10 patients with RVEF>or = 0.40 before PVR, 5 patients (50%) maintained a RVEF>or = 0.40 following PVR, whereas only 2 out of 15 patients (13%) with pre-operative values<0.40 reached an RVEF>or = 0.40 postoperatively (p<0.001).
topic: Technical limitations and potential sources of error when using radionuclide angiography to assess RV mechanics
question: In planar radionuclide angiography assessments of right ventricular volumes post-pulmonary valve replacement, which technical limitation most directly undermines accurate quantification of RV end-diastolic and end-systolic volumes, potentially explaining the apparent lack of change observed?

choices.A: Overlapping left ventricular activity obscuring RV borders
choices.B: Simplified geometrical modeling of the complex RV shape during volume calculations
choices.C: Cardiac motion blurring from low temporal resolution in gated acquisition
choices.D: Variable pulmonary and hepatic radiotracer uptake affecting background correction

explanation: Planar radionuclide angiography requires simplistic geometric assumptions to calculate RV volumes, which poorly represent the right ventricle’s irregular shape and lead to systematic errors that can mask true remodeling.

context:
Patients diagnosed with serious mental illness (SMI) who qualify for nursing home placement tend to require high levels of both psychiatric and nursing care. However, it is unknown whether they are equally likely to be admitted to nursing homes with adequate quality of care compared with other patients.

We analyzed a national cohort of more than 1.3 million new nursing home admissions in 2007 using the minimum data set. The total and healthcare-related deficiency citations for each facility were obtained from the Online Survey, Certification, and Reporting file. Bivariate and multivariate regression analyses determined the association of schizophrenia or bipolar disorder with admissions to facilities with higher deficiencies.

Compared with other patients, patients with schizophrenia (n=23,767) tended to enter nursing homes with more total (13.3 vs. 11.2, P<0.001) and healthcare-related deficiencies (8.6 vs. 7.2, P<0.001); and patients with bipolar disorder (n=19,741) were more likely to enter facilities with more problematic care too (12.5 vs. 11.2, P<0.001 for total deficiencies; and 8.2 vs. 7.2, P<0.001 for healthcare-related deficiencies). After sequentially controlling for the within-county choice of facilities, patient characteristics, and facility covariates, the association of SMI with admitting to higher-deficiency nursing homes persisted.
topic: Interpretation of P-values and mean citation differences in large cohort studies of healthcare outcomes
question: What does the P<0.001 finding for the 13.3 versus 11.2 mean total deficiencies imply in this large cohort comparison between schizophrenia patients and others?

choices.A: It demonstrates a statistically significant mean difference, but clinical importance still requires effect-size evaluation.
choices.B: It indicates a 99.9% probability that schizophrenia directly leads to higher deficiency counts.
choices.C: It shows that the large sample size makes the observed difference automatically clinically meaningful.
choices.D: It quantifies the magnitude of higher deficiencies in schizophrenia patients.

explanation: A P-value below 0.001 strongly rejects the null of equal means, yet does not measure effect size or clinical relevance.

context:
The prevalence of combined humeral and glenoid defects varies between 79 and 84 % in case of chronic posttraumatic anterior shoulder instability. The main goal of this study was to evaluate the relationship between humeral and glenoid defects based on quantitative radiological criteria.

A retrospective study was performed between 2000 and 2011 including patients who underwent primary surgical shoulder stabilization for chronic posttraumatic anterior shoulder instability, with bone defects in both the glenoid and humerus and a healthy contralateral shoulder. The following measurements were taken: D/R ratio (Hill-Sachs lesion depth/humeral head radius) on an AP X-ray in internal rotation and the D1/D2 ratio [diameter of the involved glenoid articular surfaces (D1)/the healthy one (D2)] on a comparative Bernageau glenoid profile view. Measurements were taken by two observers. Correlations were determined by the Spearman correlation coefficients (r), Bland and Altman diagrams, and intra-class correlation coefficients (ICC). A sample size calculation was done.

Thirty patients were included, 25 men/5 women, mean age 29.8 ± 11.2 years. The mean D/R was 23 ± 12 % for observer 1 and 23 ± 10 % for observer 2. The mean D1/D2 was 95 ± 4 % for observer 1 and 94 ± 6 % for observer 2. No significant correlation was found between humeral and glenoid bone defects by observer 1 (r = 0.23, p = 0.22) or observer 2 (r = 0.05, p = 0.78). Agreement of the observers for the D/R ratio was excellent (ICC = 0.89 ± 0.04, p < 0.00001) and good for the D1/D2 ratio (ICC = 0.54 ± 0.14, p = 0.006).
topic: Impact of observer variability on the measurement of humeral versus glenoid bone defects and its influence on clinical decision-making.
question: Suppose a glenoid D1/D2 ratio cutoff of 92% is used to choose between bone augmentation (<92%) and soft-tissue stabilization (≥92%). Given an inter-observer ICC of 0.54 for the D1/D2 ratio versus 0.89 for the humeral D/R ratio, what is the most likely implication for the consistency of surgical recommendations?

choices.A: The moderate ICC for the D1/D2 ratio means observers measuring values near 92% are more likely to disagree on the surgical plan compared to the D/R ratio.
choices.B: Since both ICCs exceed 0.5, both measurements will yield equally consistent surgical recommendations.
choices.C: The high ICC of the D/R ratio paradoxically means it will produce more inter-observer disagreement than the D1/D2 ratio.
choices.D: ICC values indicate that neither measurement is reliable enough to guide any surgical decision.

explanation: An ICC of 0.54 indicates only moderate inter-observer agreement, so measurements near the 92% threshold can vary between observers, leading to different treatment choices; the D/R ratio’s higher ICC (0.89) will yield more consistent recommendations.

context:
In vivo comparative gap measurements were performed in three different patella positions (reduced, subluxated and everted) using offset-type-force-controlled-spreader-system.

Prospectively, 50 knees were operated by total knee arthroplasty using a navigation-assisted gap-balancing technique. The offset-type-force-controlled-spreader-system was used for gap measurements. This commercially available instrument allows controllable tension in patella-reduced position. The mediolateral gaps of knee extension (0°) and flexion (90°) angle were recorded in three different patella positions; reduced, subluxated and everted. Any gap differences of more than 3 mm were considered as a meaningful difference. Correlation between the difference with the demographic data, preoperative radiologic alignment and intraoperative data was analysed. For statistical analysis, ANOVA and Pearson's correlation test were used.

The gaps in patella eversion demonstrated smaller gaps both in knee extension and flexion position compared to the gaps of patella reduction position. The amount of decreased gaps was more definite in knee flexion position. Statistically significant difference was observed for the lateral gap of patella eversion compared to gap of patella reduction in knee flexion position (p<0.05). There were notable cases of variability in knee flexion position. Significant portion of 12 (24 %) knees of patella subluxation and 33 (66 %) knees of patella evertion demonstrated either increased or decreased gaps in knee flexion position compared to the gaps of patella reduction position.
topic: Protocol for measuring mediolateral extension and flexion gaps at 0° and 90° knee flexion using controlled tension.
question: In a navigated gap-balancing total knee arthroplasty using an offset-type force-controlled spreader, which specific mediolateral gap change at 90° knee flexion achieved statistical significance (p<0.05) when compared to the patella-reduced condition?

choices.A: Medial gap during patella subluxation
choices.B: Lateral gap during patella eversion
choices.C: Medial gap during patella eversion
choices.D: Lateral gap during patella subluxation

explanation: Only the lateral gap measured with the patella everted at 90° flexion was significantly smaller than the lateral gap with the patella reduced (p<0.05).

context:
The purpose of this study was to delineate early respiratory predictors of mortality in children with hemato-oncology malignancy who developed acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).

We conducted a retrospective chart review of children with malignant and ARDS who needed mechanical ventilation and were admitted to a pediatric intensive care unit from January 1987 to January 1997.

Seventeen children with ARDS and malignancy aged 10.5 +/- 5.1 years were identified. Six of the 17 children (35.3%) survived. Sepsis syndrome was present in 70.6% of all the children. Peak inspiratory pressure, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP), and ventilation index values could distinguish outcome by day 3. A significant relationship between respiratory data and outcome related to efficiency of oxygenation, as determined by PaO(2)/FIO(2) and P(A-a)O(2), was present from day 8 after onset of mechanical ventilation.
topic: Interpretation of the impact of peak inspiratory pressure trends within the first 72 hours on mortality prediction in pediatric ARDS patients with malignancy.
question: In pediatric ARDS associated with malignancy, what pathophysiological mechanism explains why peak inspiratory pressure trends within the first 72 hours predict mortality before significant PaO2/FiO2 changes emerge?

choices.A: Early alterations in lung compliance and airway resistance precede overt gas exchange impairment.
choices.B: Peak inspiratory pressure directly quantifies alveolar oxygen diffusion capacity.
choices.C: PIP trends are independent of ventilator adjustments, reflecting only disease severity.
choices.D: Elevated PIP in early ARDS primarily indicates reduced cardiac output affecting oxygen delivery.

explanation: Rising PIP reflects worsening lung compliance and resistance before oxygenation fails, making it an early prognostic marker.

context:
To study the risks of haemodynamic instability, and the possible occurrence of spinal haematoma, meningitis and epidural abscess when epidural analgesia is performed for cytoreductive surgery and hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy (HIPEC).

We retrospectively analyzed the data of 35 patients treated by HIPEC with oxaliplatin or cisplatin. An epidural catheter was inserted before induction of general anaesthesia. Postoperatively, a continuous epidural infusion of ropivacain, then a patient-controlled epidural analgesia were started.

The epidural catheter was used peroperatively before HIPEC in 12 subjects (34%), and after HIPEC in 23 subjects (66%). The median dose of ropivacain given peroperatively in the epidural catheter was 40 mg (30-75). Norepinephrin was used in two subjects (6%) peroperatively (median infusion rate 0.325 μg/kg per minute [0.32-0.33]), and in four subjects (11%) in the postoperative 24 hours. No spinal haematoma, meningitis or epidural abscess were noted. Five subjects (14%) had a thrombopenia or a prothrombin time less than 60% before catheter removal. Two subjects (6%) had a leukopenia before catheter removal. No thrombopenia or blood coagulation disorders were recorded the day of catheter removal.
topic: Surveillance and management of coagulation abnormalities (thrombocytopenia, prothrombin time <60%) before safe epidural catheter removal.
question: In the immediate postoperative period following cytoreductive surgery with HIPEC, what is the most plausible mechanism leading to transient thrombocytopenia and reduced prothrombin time observed before safe epidural catheter removal?

choices.A: Direct bone marrow toxicity from platinum-based chemotherapy impairing platelet and clotting‐factor synthesis
choices.B: Dilutional coagulopathy from extensive intraoperative fluid resuscitation and blood loss
choices.C: Ropivacaine-induced platelet dysfunction and inhibition of vitamin K–dependent factors
choices.D: Norepinephrine-mediated hepatic vasoconstriction reducing synthesis of clotting factors

explanation: Massive fluids and blood loss during HIPEC cause dilution of platelets and clotting factors, leading to transient coagulopathy that normalizes once fluid balance is restored.

context:
Controlled ovarian stimulation (COS) with intrauterine insemination (IUI) is a common treatment in couples with unexplained non-conception. Induction of multifollicular growth is considered to improve pregnancy outcome, but it contains an increased risk of multiple pregnancies and ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome. In this study the impact of the number of follicles (>14 mm) on the ongoing pregnancy rate (PR) and multiple PR was evaluated in the first four treatment cycles.

A retrospective cohort study was performed in all couples with unexplained non-conception undergoing COS-IUI in the Academic Hospital of Maastricht. The main outcome measure was ongoing PR. Secondary outcomes were ongoing multiple PR, number of follicles of>or=14 mm, and order of treatment cycle.

Three hundred couples were included. No significant difference was found in ongoing PR between women with one, two, three or four follicles respectively (P=0.54), but in women with two or more follicles 12/73 pregnancies were multiples. Ongoing PR was highest in the first treatment cycle and declined significantly with increasing cycle order (P=0.006), while multiple PR did not change.
topic: Inclusion and exclusion criteria defining the study population of couples with unexplained non-conception at the Academic Hospital of Maastricht.
question: Which couple would have been eligible for inclusion in the Maastricht retrospective COS-IUI study on unexplained non‑conception?

choices.A: A 29-year-old woman with 2 years of infertility, normal semen analysis for her partner, patent tubes on hysterosalpingography, beginning her first COS-IUI cycle.
choices.B: A 35-year-old woman with 18 months of infertility and laparoscopically confirmed stage I endometriosis, normal partner tests, starting her second COS-IUI cycle.
choices.C: A 32-year-old woman with 12 months of infertility, unilateral tubal occlusion, normal semen parameters, on her first COS-IUI cycle.
choices.D: A 31-year-old woman diagnosed with polycystic ovary syndrome, 18 months of infertility, normal partner evaluation, electing COS-IUI.

explanation: The study included only couples with unexplained infertility—no identifiable female or male factors—and evaluated first four COS‑IUI cycles.

context:
To evaluate the degree to which histologic chorioamnionitis, a frequent finding in placentas submitted for histopathologic evaluation, correlates with clinical indicators of infection in the mother.

A retrospective review was performed on 52 cases with a histologic diagnosis of acute chorioamnionitis from 2,051 deliveries at University Hospital, Newark, from January 2003 to July 2003. Third-trimester placentas without histologic chorioamnionitis (n = 52) served as controls. Cases and controls were selected sequentially. Maternal medical records were reviewed for indicators of maternal infection.

Histologic chorioamnionitis was significantly associated with the usage of antibiotics (p = 0.0095) and a higher mean white blood cell count (p = 0.018). The presence of 1 or more clinical indicators was significantly associated with the presence of histologic chorioamnionitis (p = 0.019).
topic: Statistical significance testing and interpretation of p-values (p = 0.0095, p = 0.018, p = 0.019) in the context of correlational research.
question: When applying a Bonferroni correction for the three independent hypotheses tested in this study (α = 0.05/3 ≈ 0.0167), which of the reported associations remain statistically significant?

choices.A: Only the association with antibiotic usage (p = 0.0095)
choices.B: Both the associations with antibiotic usage (p = 0.0095) and higher mean WBC (p = 0.018)
choices.C: Both the associations with antibiotic usage (p = 0.0095) and clinical indicators (p = 0.019)
choices.D: All three associations remain significant

explanation: With the Bonferroni‐adjusted α of ~0.0167, only the p‐value below that threshold (0.0095) stays significant.

context:
Examine whether patients with prostate cancer choose the more aggressive of two radiotherapeutic options, whether this choice is reasoned, and what the determinants of the choice are.

One hundred fifty patients with primary prostate cancer (T(1-3)N(0)M(0)) were informed by means of a decision aid of two treatment options: radiotherapy with 70 Gy versus 74 Gy. The latter treatment is associated with more cure and more toxicity. The patients were asked whether they wanted to choose, and if so which treatment they preferred. They also assigned importance weights to the probability of various outcomes, such as survival, cure and adverse effects. Patients who wanted to choose their own treatment (n = 119) are described here.

The majority of these patients (75%) chose the lower radiation dose. Their choice was highly consistent (P<or = .001), with the importance weights assigned to the probability of survival, cure (odds ratio [OR] = 6.7 and 6.9) and late GI and genitourinary adverse effects (OR = 0.1 and 0.2). The lower dose was chosen more often by the older patients, low-risk patients, patients without hormone treatment, and patients with a low anxiety or depression score.
topic: Role of concomitant hormone therapy status in shaping radiotherapy dose decisions
question: Considering that older age, low‐risk disease, absence of concomitant hormone therapy, and low anxiety/depression independently predict choosing the lower 70 Gy dose, which of the following patient profiles is most likely to opt for the higher 74 Gy regimen?

choices.A: 68‐year‐old, low‐risk, on hormone therapy, low anxiety
choices.B: 64‐year‐old, high‐risk, on hormone therapy, high anxiety
choices.C: 72‐year‐old, low‐risk, no hormone therapy, low anxiety
choices.D: 59‐year‐old, high‐risk, no hormone therapy, low anxiety

explanation: High‐risk status, concomitant hormone therapy, higher anxiety, and younger age all favor choosing the more aggressive 74 Gy dose.

context:
To evaluate whether robotically assisted laparoscopic prostatectomy (RALP) is less invasive than radical retropubic prostatectomy (RRP), as experimental studies suggest that the acute phase reaction is proportional to surgery-induced tissue damage.

Between May and November 2006, all patients undergoing RRP or RALP in our department were prospectively assessed. Blood samples were collected 24 h before (T0), during surgery (T1), at the end of anaesthesia (T2), and 12 (T3) and 24 h after surgery (T4), and assayed for interleukin(IL)-6 and IL-1 alpha, C-reactive protein (CRP), and lactate. The Mann-Whitney U-, Student's t- and Friedman tests were used to compare continuous variables, and the Pearson chi-square and Fisher test for categorical variables, with a two-sided P<0.05 considered to indicate significance.

In all, 35 and 26 patients were assessed for RALP and RRP, respectively; the median (interquartile range) age was 62 (56-68) and 68.5 (59.2-71.2) years, respectively (P<0.009). Baseline levels (T0) of IL-1, IL-6, CRP and lactate were comparable in both arms. IL-6, CRP and lactates levels increased during both kinds of surgery. The mean IL-6 and CPR values were higher for RRP at T1 (P = 0.01 and 0.001), T2 (P = 0.001 and<0.001), T3 (P = 0.002 and<0.001) and T4 (P<0.001 and 0.02), respectively. Lactate was higher for RRP at T2 (P = 0.001), T3 (P = 0.001) and T4 (P = 0.004), although remaining within the normal ranges. IL-1 alpha did not change at the different sample times.
topic: Propose additional biomarkers or outcome measures that could strengthen the assessment of invasiveness in future prostatectomy studies.
question: Which additional biomarker would most directly quantify surgery‐induced tissue necrosis to enhance assessment of invasiveness beyond IL‐6, IL‐1α, CRP, and lactate?

choices.A: Tumor necrosis factor‐alpha (TNF‐α)
choices.B: High‐mobility group box 1 protein (HMGB1)
choices.C: Procalcitonin
choices.D: Interleukin‐10 (IL‐10)

explanation: HMGB1 is a damage‐associated molecular pattern released by necrotic cells, directly correlating with tissue injury severity and providing a more specific measure of surgical invasiveness.

context:
Implementation of the complex treatment strategies that have been shown to improve survival of patients with congestive heart failure (CHF) may require certain expertise. We wanted to examine the association between pattern of outpatient care and survival of patients with CHF.

In a retrospective cohort study conducted with national Veterans Health Administration (VHA) databases, we examined the association between the pattern of outpatient care and survival in 11,661 patients discharged from VA hospitals between October 1, 1991, and September 30, 1992, with the primary diagnosis of CHF (cohort 1). Patients were divided into 4 groups, on the basis of their pattern of outpatient care over a 12-month period after discharge: 1) general medicine clinic visits only (GM-only); 2) cardiology clinic visits only (CARD-only); 3) general medicine and cardiology (MIXED) clinic visits; and 4) neither general medicine nor cardiology clinic visits (no-GM/CARD). We used the Cox proportional hazards model to evaluate 1-year survival, controlling for clinical and demographic factors. Consistency of our results was examined by performing identical analysis on a cohort of patients discharged from VHA hospitals between October 1, 1994, and September 30, 1995 (cohort 2, n = 10,141).

The overall 1-year mortality rate was 23% in the primary cohort. The unadjusted mortality rate was highest for patients in the no-GM/CARD follow up (29%) and lowest for patients in the MIXED group (19%). By use of the MIXED group as reference and adjusting for important clinical and demographic factors, the risk of death (risk ratio [95% CI]) was 1.12 (0.94-1.34) in the CARD-only group, 1.26 (1.15-1.38) in the GM-only group, and 1.48 (1.28-1.72) in the no-GM/CARD group. Cohort-2 results were consistent with cohort 1 for most covariates, and significant survival differences were again found between GM-only and the MIXED group (1.25 [1.14-1.37]).
topic: Consideration of demographic and clinical confounders in observational studies of healthcare utilization and survival.
question: In a retrospective CHF cohort stratified by outpatient visits occurring during the first 12 months post-discharge and then assessed for 1-year mortality, which bias arises because patients must survive long enough to register a visit, artificially improving survival in the visit-based groups?

choices.A: Confounding by indication
choices.B: Immortal time bias
choices.C: Lead-time bias
choices.D: Informative censoring bias

explanation: Classifying exposure based on visits accrued during follow-up creates periods during which death cannot occur before exposure is assigned, thus introducing immortal time bias.

context:
Tacrolimus is a potent immunosuppressive drug used in organ transplantation. Because of its substantial toxic effects, narrow therapeutic index, and interindividual pharmacokinetic variability, therapeutic drug monitoring of whole-blood tacrolimus concentrations has been recommended. We investigated the comparability of the results of 2 immunoassay systems, affinity column-mediated immunoassay (ACMIA) and microparticle enzyme immunoassay (MEIA), comparing differences in the tacrolimus concentrations measured by the 2 methods in relation to the hematologic and biochemical values of hepatic and renal functions.

A total of 154 samples from kidney or liver transplant recipients were subjected to Dimension RxL HM with a tacrolimus Flex reagent cartilage for the ACMIA method and IMx tacrolimus II for the MEIA method.

Tacrolimus concentrations measured by the ACMIA method (n = 154) closely correlated with those measured by the MEIA method (r = 0.84). The Bland-Altman plot using concentration differences between the 2 methods and the average of the 2 methods showed no specific trends. The tacrolimus levels determined by both the MEIA method and the ACMIA method were not influenced by hematocrit levels, but the difference between the 2 methods (ACMIA - MEIA) tended to be larger in low hematocrit samples (P<.001).
topic: Comparative study design considerations when evaluating two immunoassay platforms in transplant patient samples.
question: In a comparative evaluation of two immunoassays for whole‐blood tacrolimus, a Bland‐Altman plot of differences versus mean concentrations showed no trend, yet larger assay differences were found in low‐hematocrit samples. Which analysis most directly quantifies this hematocrit‐dependent bias?

choices.A: Perform Deming regression between the two assay measurements.
choices.B: Conduct separate Bland‐Altman analyses stratified by hematocrit tertiles.
choices.C: Plot assay differences against hematocrit values and fit a linear regression.
choices.D: Calculate the intraclass correlation coefficient within the low‐hematocrit subgroup.

explanation: Directly plotting the difference versus hematocrit and applying regression quantifies how bias varies with hematocrit, isolating the matrix effect.

context:
Using murine models, we have shown that the lysosomotropic amine, chloroquine, is effective in the prevention of graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) mediated by donor T cells reactive with recipient minor histocompatibility antigens (MiHCs). Because lysosomotropic amines can suppress major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class II antigen presentation, their mechanism of action is potentially different from current immune suppressant drugs used to control GVHD such as cyclosporine.

We investigated the use of cyclosporine and the lysosomotropic amines chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine in combination for additive or synergistic immunosuppression on T-cell responses in vitro to MiHC and MHC in mice.

We found that similar concentrations of chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine suppress the T-cell response to MiHC in mice (C57BL/6 anti-BALB.B) and that lysosomotropic amines in combination with cyclosporine result in synergistic suppression of a proliferative response to MiHC. Similar suppression and synergy appear to be present in an alloreactive response (C57BL/6 anti-BALB/c). Direct inhibition by chloroquine of T-cell proliferative responses induced by anti-CD3epsilon in the absence of antigen-presenting cells is present at higher concentrations than that required to suppress responses to MiHC or MHC. Chloroquine appears to induce decreased T-cell viability at high concentrations. This effect does not appear to be due to decreased T-cell production of interleukin-2 or interferon-gamma. At lower concentrations (<25 microg/ml), chloroquine can also decrease the ability of antigen-presenting cells to stimulate an a C57BL/6 anti-BALB/c T-cell response and can inhibit MHC class II expression after activation with lipopolysaccharide.
topic: Role of subcytotoxic chloroquine concentrations (<25 µg/ml) in impairing antigen-presenting cell function and induced MHC class II expression after LPS activation.
question: Subcytotoxic concentrations of chloroquine (<25 µg/ml) impair antigen-presenting cell function by inhibiting LPS-induced MHC class II expression. Which lysosomal mechanism most directly explains this effect?

choices.A: Activation of vacuolar H⁺-ATPase increasing lysosomal acidity and denaturing MHC II molecules
choices.B: Chelation of intravesicular calcium that disrupts MHC II–peptide complex transport to the cell surface
choices.C: Elevation of endosomal pH that prevents proteolytic removal of the invariant chain, blocking peptide loading
choices.D: Inhibition of autophagosome–lysosome fusion, reducing delivery of peptides for MHC II loading

explanation: Chloroquine accumulates in acidic vesicles and raises their pH, inhibiting proteases that remove the invariant chain and thus preventing peptide loading onto MHC II.

context:
The aim of this study was to determine whether bone scans (BS) can be avoided if pelvis was included in CT thorax and abdomen to detect bony metastases from breast cancer.

Results of 77 pairs of CT (thorax, abdomen, and pelvis) and BS in newly diagnosed patients with metastatic breast cancer (MBC) were compared prospectively for 12 months. Both scans were blindly assessed by experienced radiologists and discussed at multidisciplinary team meetings regarding the diagnosis of bone metastases.

CT detected metastatic bone lesions in 43 (98%) of 44 patients with bone metastases. The remaining patient had a solitary, asymptomatic bony metastasis in shaft of femur. BS was positive in all patients with bone metastases. There were 11 cases of false positive findings on BS.
topic: Radiation exposure comparison between combined CT thorax–abdomen–pelvis and conventional bone scintigraphy.
question: In this cohort of 77 patients, bone scintigraphy identified 44 true‐positive and 11 false‐positive results for bone metastases. What is the positive predictive value (PPV) of bone scintigraphy in this study?
explanation: PPV = true positives / (true positives + false positives) = 44 / (44 + 11) = 44/55 ≈ 80%.

context:
Seventeen patients, aged 7-54 years (mean of 37.2 year), were treated by pulpotomy and filling with ProRoot MTA(®)  in premolar or molar teeth with vital pulps and without clinical evidence of irreversible pulpitis. The patients were then followed up for 12 to 24 months and the teeth then assessed by clinical and radiographic examination. Statistical analysis was performed with Kaplan-Meier survival probability statistics to estimate the survival of the treated teeth.

At 24 months, the survival rate without any complementary treatment was estimated to be 82%. Two of the 17 treated teeth required root canal treatment for pain control and one for prosthetic reasons.
topic: Step-by-step clinical protocol for performing pulpotomy and placement of ProRoot MTA
question: In a single-arm study of pulpotomy with ProRoot MTA on 17 vital posterior teeth, Kaplan-Meier analysis yielded an 82% survival rate at 24 months without additional treatment, while failures included two cases needing root canal therapy for pain and one for prosthetic reasons. Which statement best describes a limitation of the Kaplan-Meier method in this context of competing risks?

choices.A: It overestimates the cumulative incidence of the observed failure event because competing events are treated as censored.
choices.B: It underestimates the hazard of failure by combining all failure modes into a single curve.
choices.C: It properly distinguishes between different failure types and yields unbiased incidence measures.
choices.D: It provides identical results to the cumulative incidence function when competing risks are present.

explanation: Kaplan-Meier treats competing events as censored observations, thus yielding an inflated estimate of the event of interest’s incidence.

context:
Although the retroperitoneal approach has been the preferred choice for open urological procedures, retroperitoneoscopy is not the preferred approach for laparoscopy. This study aims to develop a training model for retroperitoneoscopy and to establish an experimental learning curve.

Fifteen piglets were operated on to develop a standard retroperitoneoscopic nephrectomy (RPN) training model. All procedures were performed with three ports. Intraoperative data (side, operative time, blood loss, peritoneal opening) were recorded. Animals were divided into groups A, the first eight, and B, the last seven cases. Data were statistically analyzed.

We performed fifteen RPNs. The operative time varied from 15 to 50 minutes (median 30 minutes). Blood loss varied from 5 to 100 mL (median 20 mL). We experienced five peritoneal openings; we had two surgical vascular complications managed laparoscopically. There was statistical difference between groups A and B for peritoneal opening (p = 0.025), operative time (p = 0.0037), and blood loss (p = 0.026).

RPN in a porcine model could simulate the whole procedure, from creating the space to nephrectomy completion. Experimental learning curve was eight cases, after statistical data analysis.
topic: Standardized three‑port placement technique for retroperitoneoscopic nephrectomy and its ergonomic implications
question: Which biomechanical rationale best explains how the standardized three‑port configuration reduces peritoneal tearing as the surgeon gains experience in retroperitoneoscopic nephrectomy?

choices.A: The optimized fulcrum‑to‑target distance reduces lever‑arm torque on the posterior peritoneum.
choices.B: Symmetrical port spacing enhances direct line‑of‑sight to the kidney but does not influence peritoneal tension.
choices.C: Increased lateral separation of ports lowers insufflation pressure, thereby decreasing peritoneal stress.
choices.D: Medial positioning of the camera port centralizes the instrument mass, minimizing collisions without affecting peritoneal integrity.

explanation: Standardizing port positions optimizes instrument fulcrum mechanics, reducing lever‑arm torque and shear forces on the peritoneum, which decreases tearing as ergonomic proficiency is achieved.

context:
Multislice helical computed tomography (CT), which can provide detailed 2-D and 3-D reconstructed images, is useful in imaging diagnosis for dental implant treatment. Therefore, in this study, it was performed to clarify the mandibular depiction of double-oblique reconstructed images when changing their thickness.

A total of 38 sites in the mandibular molar region were examined using multislice helical CT. The thicknesses of the double-oblique images using multislice helical CT scans were reconstructed in 4 conditions: 0.3 mm, 0.9 mm, 1.6 mm, and 4.1 mm. In double-oblique images, mandibular depiction was evaluated by 5 oral radiologists using a subjective rating score.

In the alveolar crest and the whole of the mandibular canal, the highest value was obtained with 0.9 mm-thick images; however, there was no significant difference between 0.3 mm and 0.9 mm-thick images.
topic: Sample selection and site distribution considerations in mandibular CT studies (38 molar sites)
question: Which reconstructed slice thickness in double-oblique mandibular CT provides the optimal balance of maintaining alveolar crest and mandibular canal depiction equivalent to the thinnest slices while reducing image noise and dataset size?

choices.A: 0.3 mm
choices.B: 0.9 mm
choices.C: 1.6 mm
choices.D: 4.1 mm

explanation: Although 0.3 mm slices offer maximum resolution, 0.9 mm slices achieve the highest depiction scores (not significantly different from 0.3 mm) and benefit from lower noise and smaller data volume.

context:
To explore whether early treatment would shorten the duration of headache from headache onset to its peak and reduce headache severity at peak.

Prior clinical studies almost exclusively focused on headache relief after dosing. No data are available on whether early intervention affects the duration from headache onset to peak and headache severity at peak.

Adult migraineurs were enrolled in this observational study from multi-site headache clinics. Patients recorded their migraine experiences via an electronic diary over 1 month. Patients reported the time and pain severity at onset, dosing, and peak. We used a linear mixed model to evaluate the impact of the timing of treatment and to adjust for covariates and correlation of observations within subjects.

A total of 182 patients reported 970 migraine episodes, 620 of which were treated before headaches progressed to peak. Mean time from headache onset to peak varied from 1.9 hours to 8.9 hours for patients treated within 15 minutes of onset and those who waited for 4 or more hours, respectively. However, early intervention was not associated with reduced headache severity at peak. In multivariate analysis, early treatment, use of triptans, and mild migraine headache in the past 3 months were significantly associated with shorter time from onset to headache peak. A separate model indicated that the timing of medication was not associated with the duration between dosing and headache peak, but use of triptans shortened the time from dosing to headache peak.
topic: Methodology for recording and defining the time and pain severity at migraine onset, dosing, and headache peak.
question: Based on the study’s multivariate mixed‐model analyses, which statement best captures the distinct impacts of treatment timing versus triptan use on the migraine progression intervals?

choices.A: Both early treatment and triptan use independently shorten the interval from dosing to headache peak, but only early treatment reduces onset‐to‐peak.
choices.B: Early treatment reduces only the onset‐to‐peak interval, whereas triptan use shortens both the onset‐to‐peak and dosing‐to‐peak intervals.
choices.C: Neither early treatment nor triptan use affects the dosing‐to‐peak interval, but early treatment still shortens onset‐to‐peak.
choices.D: Triptan use shortens the onset‐to‐peak interval but paradoxically prolongs the dosing‐to‐peak interval, while early treatment impacts only dosing‐to‐peak.

explanation: Early intervention and triptan use both shorten onset‐to‐peak, but only triptans, not timing, shorten dosing‐to‐peak.

context:
Tethering of the spinal cord is thought to increase the chance of neurological injury when scoliosis correction is undertaken. All patients with myelomeningocele (MM) are radiographically tethered, and untethering procedures carry significant morbidity risks including worsening neurological function and wound complications. No guidelines exist as regards untethering in patients with MM prior to scoliosis correction surgery. The authors' aim in this study was to evaluate their experience in patients with MM who were not untethered before scoliosis correction.

Seventeen patients with MM were retrospectively identified and 1) had no evidence of a clinically symptomatic tethered cord, 2) had undergone spinal fusion for scoliosis correction, and 3) had not been untethered for at least 1 year prior to surgery. The minimum follow-up after fusion was 2 years. Charts and radiographs were reviewed for neurological or shunt complications in the perioperative period.

The average age of the patients was 12.4 years, and the following neurological levels were affected: T-12 and above, 7 patients; L-1/L-2, 6 patients; L-3, 2 patients; and L-4, 2 patients. All were radiographically tethered as confirmed on MR imaging. Fourteen of the patients (82%) had a ventriculoperitoneal shunt. The mean Cobb angle was corrected from 82 degrees to 35 degrees , for a 57% correction. All patients underwent neuromonitoring of their upper extremities, and some underwent lower extremity monitoring as well. Postoperatively, no patient experienced a new cranial nerve palsy, shunt malfunction, change in urological function, or upper extremity weakness/sensory loss. One patient had transient lower extremity weakness, which returned to baseline within 1 month of surgery.
topic: Methodological considerations and limitations inherent in retrospective cohort designs assessing surgical outcomes.
question: In assessing the safety of performing scoliosis correction without prior untethering in this retrospective cohort, which methodological limitation most undermines the ability to draw causal conclusions about comparative complication risks?

choices.A: Exclusion of clinically symptomatic tethered cord patients, creating selection bias toward lower‐risk individuals
choices.B: Absence of a contemporaneous control group of patients who underwent prophylactic untethering, preventing direct risk comparison
choices.C: Potential observer bias in detecting postoperative complications due to reliance on retrospective chart review
choices.D: Follow-up limited to two years, which may miss late-onset neurological sequelae

explanation: Without a control arm of untethered patients, one cannot directly compare complication rates, leaving causal inferences about the safety of omitting untethering unsupported.

context:
The purpose of this study was to investigate the efficacy of ultrasonography to confirm Schanz pin placement in a cadaveric model, and the interobserver repeatability of the ultrasound methodology.

This investigation is a repeated measures cadaveric study with multiple examiners.

Cadaveric preparation and observations were done by an orthopaedic traumatologist and resident, and two general surgery traumatologists.

A total of 16 Schanz pins were equally placed in bilateral femora and tibiae. Four examiners took measurements of pin protrusion beyond the distal cortices using first ultrasonography and then by direct measurement after gross dissection.MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE(S): Distal Schanz pin protrusion length measurements from both ultrasonography and direct measurement post dissection.

Schanz pin protrusion measurements are underestimated by ultrasonography (p<0.01) by an average of 10 percent over the range of 5 to 18 mm, and they display a proportional bias that increases the under reporting as the magnitude of pin protrusion increases. Ultrasound data demonstrate good linear correlation and closely represent actual protrusion values in the 5 to 12 mm range. Interobserver repeatability analysis demonstrated that all examiners were not statistically different in their measurements despite minimal familiarity with the ultrasound methodology (p>0.8).
topic: Potential training and familiarity requirements to improve ultrasonography measurement accuracy.
question: Which measurement error model best characterizes the ultrasonography‑based protrusion length assessments in the study, given their consistent underestimation and increasing bias at larger protrusion magnitudes?

choices.A: Additive systematic bias with a constant offset
choices.B: Proportional systematic bias
choices.C: Purely random heteroscedastic error
choices.D: Examiner‑dependent differential bias

explanation: The underestimation increases as true protrusion length grows, indicating a systematic error proportional to the measurement magnitude.

context:
Oncology literature cites that only 2% to 4% of patients participate in research. Up to 85% of patients are unaware that clinical trials research is being conducted at their treatment facility or that they might be eligible to participate.

It was hypothesized that patients' satisfaction with information regarding clinical trials would improve after targeted educational interventions, and accruals to clinical trials would increase in the year following those interventions.

All new patients referred to the cancer center over a 4-month period were mailed a baseline survey to assess their knowledge of clinical research. Subsequently, educational interventions were provided, including an orientation session highlighting clinical trials, a pamphlet, and a reference to a clinical trials Web site. A postintervention survey was sent to the responders of the initial survey 3 months after the initial mailing.

Patient satisfaction with information significantly increased after the interventions. There was no increase in subsequent enrollment in clinical trials. Patients who indicated an inclination to participate in clinical trials tended to have greater satisfaction with the information they received.
topic: Potential confounding factors, biases (such as response bias or selection bias), and limitations inherent in the study design.
question: In the evaluation of improved patient satisfaction, which methodological flaw most likely led to an overestimation of the educational interventions’ true effect?

choices.A: Recall bias from patients misremembering their baseline knowledge
choices.B: Selection bias arising from surveying only those who returned the initial questionnaire
choices.C: Observer-expectancy bias due to researchers influencing patient responses
choices.D: Instrumentation bias from using different satisfaction scales before and after the intervention

explanation: Only initial responders were eligible for the postintervention survey, causing selection bias by excluding nonresponders who may have had different satisfaction levels.

context:
Cytokine concentration in pancreatic juice of patients with pancreatic disease is unknown. Secretin stimulation allows endoscopic collection of pancreatic juice secreted into the duodenum. We aimed to evaluate the cytokine concentrations in pancreatic juice of patients with abdominal pain to discriminate presence from absence of pancreatic disease.

From January 2003-December 2004, consecutive patients with abdominal pain compatible with pancreatic origin were enrolled. Patients underwent upper endoscopy. Intravenous secretin (0.2 mug/kg) was given immediately before scope intubation. Pancreatic juice collected from the duodenum was immediately snap-frozen in liquid nitrogen until assays were performed. Pancreatic juice levels of interleukin-8, interleukin-6, intercellular adhesion molecule 1, and transforming growth factor-beta 1 were measured by modified enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays. The final diagnosis was made by the primary gastroenterologist on the basis of medical history; laboratory, endoscopic, and imaging studies; and clinical follow-up. Fisher exact test and Kruskal-Wallis rank sum test were used for statistical analysis.

Of 130 patients screened, 118 met the inclusion criteria. Multivariate analysis revealed that only interleukin-8 was able to discriminate between normal pancreas and chronic pancreatitis (P = .011), pancreatic cancer (P = .044), and the presence of pancreatic diseases (P = .007). Individual cytokine concentrations were not significantly different in chronic pancreatitis compared with pancreatic cancer.
topic: Rationale for measuring cytokine concentrations in pancreatic juice to discriminate pancreatic disease presence.
question: In a multivariate analysis of cytokine concentrations in secretin-stimulated pancreatic juice, only interleukin-8 remained a significant discriminator of pancreatic disease while interleukin-6, ICAM-1, and TGF-β1 did not; which statistical phenomenon most likely explains the loss of significance for these other cytokines despite their known biological roles?

choices.A: Multicollinearity among the cytokine predictors leading to unstable coefficient estimates
choices.B: Application of a Bonferroni correction making the significance threshold overly stringent
choices.C: Simpson’s paradox caused by uneven distribution of disease subtypes
choices.D: Violation of normality assumptions in nonparametric data

explanation: When predictors are highly correlated, multicollinearity inflates variance of coefficient estimates, causing loss of individual significance in multivariate models.

context:
Congenital cytomegalovirus infection is currently the leading cause of congenital infection in 0.2-2.2% of live births worldwide leading to variable serious sequalae. The aim of the study was to determine if low birth weight is an indicator of CMV congenital infection evidenced by detecting CMV-DNA in umbilical cord blood at the time of delivery.

CMV-IgG and IgM antibodies and CMV-DNAemia were assessed in umbilical cord blood of two hundreds newborns, one hundred of whom had birth weight<or = 2700 gram and/or head circumference<or = 32 cm.

CMV-IgM was not detected, while CMV-IgG was positive in 80-90% of the two hundreds tested newborns. CMV-DNA was detected in four out of the 200 newborns. One of them was over the adopted weight limit (>2700 gram).
topic: Critique the study design and suggest methodological enhancements for future research on congenital CMV detection.
question: Given the low detection rate of CMV-DNA in umbilical cord blood alone, which methodological enhancement would most effectively improve the sensitivity of congenital CMV diagnosis in a similar future study?

choices.A: Expand the cohort to include a larger number of low birth weight infants for greater statistical power.
choices.B: Supplement cord blood testing with neonatal saliva or urine PCR within the first three weeks of life to capture higher viral loads.
choices.C: Incorporate maternal CMV-IgM and CMV-DNA assessments during pregnancy to correlate maternal viremia with neonatal infection.
choices.D: Switch from qualitative to quantitative PCR on cord blood to detect lower levels of viral DNA.

explanation: Testing neonatal saliva or urine via PCR in the first weeks postpartum is the gold standard for congenital CMV detection due to higher viral loads than in cord blood, markedly improving diagnostic sensitivity.

context:
The purpose of this study was to determine if registered dietitian (RD) and registered nurse (RN) certified diabetes educators (CDEs) provide similar recommendations regarding carbohydrates and dietary supplements to individuals with diabetes.

A survey was mailed to CDEs in the southern United States. Participants were asked to indicate their recommendations for use of carbohydrates, fiber, artificial sweeteners, and 12 selected dietary and herbal supplements when counseling individuals with diabetes.

The survey sample consisted of 366 CDEs: 207 were RNs and 159 were RDs. No statistically significant differences were found between RNs and RDs in typical carbohydrate recommendations for treatment of diabetes. However, RDs were more likely than RNs to make recommendations for fiber intake or use of the glycemic index. A significant difference also was found in the treatment of hypoglycemia: RNs were more likely than RDs to recommend consuming a carbohydrate source with protein to treat hypoglycemia.
topic: Survey study design and methodology used to compare carbohydrate and supplement recommendations by RD and RN CDEs.
question: In comparing RDs and RNs across multiple dietary recommendation outcomes in this survey, which sequential procedure offers a more powerful alternative to the traditional Bonferroni correction while still controlling the family-wise Type I error rate?

choices.A: Tukey’s honestly significant difference test
choices.B: Holm–Bonferroni procedure
choices.C: Kaplan–Meier adjustment
choices.D: Benjamini–Hochberg false discovery rate

explanation: The Holm–Bonferroni procedure is a stepwise method that controls the family-wise error rate and is uniformly more powerful than the simple Bonferroni correction.

context:
Using murine models, we have shown that the lysosomotropic amine, chloroquine, is effective in the prevention of graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) mediated by donor T cells reactive with recipient minor histocompatibility antigens (MiHCs). Because lysosomotropic amines can suppress major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class II antigen presentation, their mechanism of action is potentially different from current immune suppressant drugs used to control GVHD such as cyclosporine.

We investigated the use of cyclosporine and the lysosomotropic amines chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine in combination for additive or synergistic immunosuppression on T-cell responses in vitro to MiHC and MHC in mice.

We found that similar concentrations of chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine suppress the T-cell response to MiHC in mice (C57BL/6 anti-BALB.B) and that lysosomotropic amines in combination with cyclosporine result in synergistic suppression of a proliferative response to MiHC. Similar suppression and synergy appear to be present in an alloreactive response (C57BL/6 anti-BALB/c). Direct inhibition by chloroquine of T-cell proliferative responses induced by anti-CD3epsilon in the absence of antigen-presenting cells is present at higher concentrations than that required to suppress responses to MiHC or MHC. Chloroquine appears to induce decreased T-cell viability at high concentrations. This effect does not appear to be due to decreased T-cell production of interleukin-2 or interferon-gamma. At lower concentrations (<25 microg/ml), chloroquine can also decrease the ability of antigen-presenting cells to stimulate an a C57BL/6 anti-BALB/c T-cell response and can inhibit MHC class II expression after activation with lipopolysaccharide.
topic: Evaluation of hydroxychloroquine’s immunosuppressive potency relative to chloroquine in the context of minor histocompatibility–driven T-cell responses.
question: The synergistic suppression of minor histocompatibility antigen–driven T-cell proliferation by combining cyclosporine with hydroxychloroquine most likely arises from which complementary mechanisms?

choices.A: Both drugs elevate endosomal pH to block MHC class II antigen processing.
choices.B: Cyclosporine inhibits calcineurin-dependent T-cell activation, while hydroxychloroquine impairs endosomal acidification required for peptide loading onto MHC class II in APCs.
choices.C: Hydroxychloroquine directly antagonizes the IL-2 receptor on T cells, and cyclosporine disrupts MHC class II–mediated antigen presentation.
choices.D: Cyclosporine prevents NF-κB activation in APCs, enhancing hydroxychloroquine’s induction of T-cell apoptosis.

explanation: Cyclosporine blocks the calcineurin–NFAT pathway in T cells, and hydroxychloroquine raises endosomal pH to inhibit antigen processing and MHC class II presentation in APCs, accounting for their synergistic suppression.

context:
A tonsillectomy audit was carried out and compared with other studies, to emphasize the role of antibiotics.

This study was carried out at North West Armed Forces Hospital, Tabuk, Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, during the year January 1999 through to December 1999. This is a retrospective study of patients who had tonsillectomy with or with adenoidectomy, the topics audited included indication for surgery, grade of surgeon, method of surgery, length of hospital stay, complications and the use of postoperative antibiotics.

A total of 185 patients underwent tonsillectomy with or without adenoidectomy. The patients age ranged between 2 years to 53 years and the majority were children. In our audit we found no difference with regard to grade of surgeons, method of hemostasis in the outcome of surgery. Moreover, postoperative antibiotics had no role in pain control, postoperative fever, secondary hemorrhage or reduction in hospital stay. The administration of analgesics on the basis of, as required, had poor pain control.
topic: Recommendations for future research or practice changes based on the audit’s conclusions
question: Considering the finding that as-needed analgesic administration resulted in suboptimal pain control after tonsillectomy, which study design and primary endpoint would most effectively assess the efficacy of a scheduled multimodal analgesic regimen?

choices.A: Double-blind randomized trial comparing scheduled multimodal analgesia versus PRN dosing with total opioid consumption over the first 72 hours as the primary endpoint.
choices.B: Prospective cohort study of scheduled paracetamol only versus PRN NSAID with length of hospital stay as the primary endpoint.
choices.C: Randomized crossover trial of intraoperative nerve block versus placebo assessing pain scores every 6 hours for 24 hours.
choices.D: Retrospective case-control study comparing analgesic regimens and measuring incidence of secondary hemorrhage.

explanation: Only a double-blind randomized trial directly compares scheduled versus PRN regimens under controlled conditions, using total opioid consumption—an objective, validated measure of analgesic efficacy.

context:
Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) levels can show wide fluctuations when repeatedly measured. Here we investigatewd if: (a) biopsy timing influences the prostate cancer (PC) detection rate in patients with fluctuating PSA (flu-PSA) in comparison with patients with steadily increasing PSA (si-PSA); (b) PSA slope estimated in patients with flu-PSA predicts a different risk of cancer detection; (c) flu-PSA and si-PSA patients develop PC in topographically different sites; (d) the behaviour of pre-operative PSA is an expression of a disease with defferent characteristics to the following radical prostatectomy.

The study involved 211 patients who underwent at least a second biopsy after a first negative prostate biopsy. PSA Slope, PSA velocity (PSAV) and PSA doubling time (PSADT) were estimated. Flu-PSA level was defined as a PSA series with at least one PSA value lower than the one immediately preceding it.

82 patients had flu-PSA levels and 129 si-PSA levels. There were no significant differences between the two groups in terms of cancer detection, clinical or pathological stage, but the si-PSA group with cancer had a higher Gleason score. No difference was found for PSA Slope between flu-PSA patients with cancer and those without.
topic: Methodological rationale and statistical considerations for timing repeat prostate biopsies in patients with flu-PSA compared to si-PSA.
question: In designing a biopsy strategy, what does the higher Gleason score observed in patients with steadily increasing PSA suggest about PSA trajectory and tumor aggressiveness?

choices.A: Consistent PSA rises between biopsies are indicative of more aggressive tumor biology.
choices.B: PSA fluctuations confer a protective effect, leading to lower-grade tumors.
choices.C: PSA slope independent of trajectory is the primary determinant of tumor grade.
choices.D: The Gleason score difference is most likely due to sampling bias rather than PSA pattern.

explanation: The finding that the si-PSA group had higher Gleason scores indicates that a steady increase in PSA reflects more aggressive prostate cancer characteristics.

context:
To describe the biomechanical and wound healing characteristics of corneas after excimer laser keratorefractive surgery.

Histologic, ultrastructural, and cohesive tensile strength evaluations were performed on 25 normal human corneal specimens, 206 uncomplicated LASIK specimens, 17 uncomplicated sub-Bowman's keratomileusis (SBK) specimens, 4 uncomplicated photorefractive keratectomy (PRK) specimens, 2 uncomplicated advanced surface ablation (ASA) specimens, 5 keratoconus specimens, 12 postoperative LASIK ectasia specimens, and 1 postoperative PRK ectasia specimen and compared to previously published studies.

Histologic and ultrastructural studies of normal corneas showed significant differences in the direction of collagen fibrils and/or the degree of lamellar interweaving in Bowman's layer, the anterior third of the corneal stroma, the posterior two-thirds of the corneal stroma, and Descemet's membrane. Cohesive tensile strength testing directly supported these morphologic findings as the stronger, more rigid regions of the cornea were located anteriorly and peripherally. This suggests that PRK and ASA, and secondarily SBK, should be biomechanically safer than conventional LASIK with regard to risk for causing keratectasia after surgery. Because adult human corneal stromal wounds heal slowly and incompletely, all excimer laser keratorefractive surgical techniques still have some distinct disadvantages due to inadequate reparative wound healing. Despite reducing some of the risk for corneal haze compared to conventional PRK, ASA cases still can develop corneal haze or breakthrough haze from the hypercellular fibrotic stromal scarring. In contrast, similar to conventional LASIK, SBK still has the short- and long-term potential for interface wound complications from the hypocellular primitive stromal scar.
topic: Comparative analysis of ectasia risk in PRK, ASA, SBK, and conventional LASIK based on anterior stromal preservation
question: Which ultrastructural feature of the anterior corneal stroma primarily accounts for its superior cohesive tensile strength and explains why surface ablation procedures carry a lower risk of postoperative ectasia compared to flap-based techniques?

choices.A: The increased diameter of collagen fibrils in the anterior stroma.
choices.B: The oblique interweaving of collagen lamellae providing enhanced cross‑lamellar reinforcement.
choices.C: The parallel alignment of collagen fibrils oriented along the visual axis.
choices.D: The higher density of keratocytes promoting rapid stromal regeneration.

explanation: The anterior stroma’s superior strength arises from oblique interweaving of collagen lamellae, which is preserved in surface ablation procedures, reducing ectasia risk.

context:
The incidence of colorectal cancer in young patients is increasing. It remains unclear if the disease has unique features in this age group.

This was a single-center, retrospective cohort study which included patients diagnosed with colorectal cancer at age ≤40 years in 1997-2013 matched 1:2 by year of diagnosis with consecutive colorectal cancer patients diagnosed at age>50 years during the same period. Patients aged 41-50 years were not included in the study, to accentuate potential age-related differences. Clinicopathological characteristics, treatment, and outcome were compared between groups.

The cohort included 330 patients, followed for a median time of 65.9 months (range 4.7-211). Several significant differences were noted. The younger group had a different ethnic composition. They had higher rates of family history of colorectal cancer (p = 0.003), hereditary colorectal cancer syndromes (p < 0.0001), and inflammatory bowel disease (p = 0.007), and a lower rate of polyps (p < 0.0001). They were more likely to present with stage III or IV disease (p = 0.001), angiolymphatic invasion, signet cell ring adenocarcinoma, and rectal tumors (p = 0.02). Younger patients more frequently received treatment. Young patients had a worse estimated 5-year disease-free survival rate (57.6  vs. 70 %, p = 0.039), but this did not retain significance when analyzed by stage (p = 0.092). Estimated 5-year overall survival rates were 59.1 and 62.1 % in the younger and the control group, respectively (p = 0.565).
topic: Future research directions to clarify unique biological behaviors and management strategies for early-onset CRC.
question: Among the distinct features of early-onset colorectal cancer—markedly higher rates of hereditary syndromes and inflammatory bowel disease, coupled with lower adenomatous polyp prevalence and enrichment for signet ring cell histology—which research approach would most powerfully clarify the unique tumorigenesis pathways in this population?

choices.A: Longitudinal colonoscopic surveillance studies to characterize polyp progression
choices.B: Integrative analysis combining germline predisposition variants with tumor somatic mutation profiles
choices.C: Epigenomic mapping of microsatellite instability across tumor specimens
choices.D: Comparative proteomic profiling of tumor versus adjacent normal tissue

explanation: Integrative germline–somatic mutation mapping directly links inherited risk factors with acquired driver events, illuminating unique oncogenic pathways bypassing the classic adenoma‑carcinoma sequence.

context:
To examine age-related differences in the relationship between personality and coping strategies in an Australian population of psychiatric inpatients.

Consenting eligible adults (N=238) from 18-100 years of age consecutively admitted to inpatient psychiatry units were assessed using the SCID I and II, the Coping Orientations to Problems Experienced Scale (COPE), the Brief Psychiatric Rating Scale (BPRS), the Global Assessment of Functioning Scale (GAF), the Social and Occupational Functioning Assessment Scale (SOFAS), the 12 Item Short-Form Heath Survey (SF12), the Sarason Social Support Questionnaire, and the NEO Five Factor Inventory (NEO-FFI) (cognitively impaired, and non-English speaking patients were excluded).

Older adults reported less symptomatology than younger patients and younger patients described more personality dysfunction than older patients. As assessed by the COPE, older adults reported lower levels of dysfunctional coping strategies than younger adults. Personality traits, social supports, gender, and age predicted coping strategies, while Axis I diagnosis, education, personality disorder, and symptom severity were not significant predictors of coping strategies.
topic: Critique the role of the Sarason Social Support Questionnaire in predicting coping strategies and explore alternative measures of social support in psychiatric research.
question: Considering that social support predicted coping strategies but was assessed only by the Sarason Social Support Questionnaire, which core limitation of the SSQ might hinder understanding the mechanisms linking support to coping, and which alternative instrument best addresses this gap?

choices.A: The SSQ does not capture structural network size and density; Social Network Index
choices.B: The SSQ fails to differentiate functional subtypes of support (emotional, informational, tangible); Interpersonal Support Evaluation List
choices.C: The SSQ ignores negative exchanges and conflict in relationships; Nagging Social Exchange Scale
choices.D: The SSQ overlooks perceived reciprocity and equity in relationships; Social Support Reciprocity Scale

explanation: The Sarason SSQ measures only number and satisfaction, lacking functional subtypes of support, while the ISEL explicitly assesses distinct support functions.

context:
The intent of this study was to determine if the use of a single or combination of static foot posture measurements can be used to predict rearfoot, midfoot, and forefoot plantar surface area in individuals with pronated or normal foot types.

Twelve foot measurements were collected on 52 individuals (mean age 25.8 years) with the change in midfoot width used to place subjects in a pronated or normal foot mobility group. Dynamic plantar contact area was collected during walking with a pressure sensor platform. The 12 measures were entered into a stepwise regression analysis to determine the optimal set of measures associated with regional plantar surface area.

A two variable model was found to describe the relationship between the foot measurements and forefoot plantar contact area (r(2)=0.79, p<0.0001). A four variable model was found to describe the relationship between the foot measurements and midfoot plantar contact area (r(2)=0.85, p<0.0001) in those individuals with a 1.26cm or greater change in midfoot width.
topic: Statistical principles and justification for using stepwise regression analysis in biomechanical research.
question: In a biomechanical study using stepwise regression with 12 candidate predictors and only 52 participants, which alternative statistical method most directly addresses overfitting and variable‐selection instability inherent in traditional stepwise procedures?

choices.A: Increasing the p‑value threshold for variable entry
choices.B: Ridge regression
choices.C: LASSO regression
choices.D: Hierarchical multiple regression

explanation: LASSO regression applies an L1 penalty that shrinks some coefficients exactly to zero, performing simultaneous variable selection and regularization to reduce overfitting and improve stability in small‑sample, high‑dimensional settings.

context:
Noise exposure in the neonatal intensive care unit is believed to be a risk factor for hearing loss in preterm neonates. Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) devices exceed recommended noise levels. High flow nasal cannulae (HFNC) are an increasingly popular alternative to CPAP for treating preterm infants, but there are no in vivo studies assessing noise production by HFNC.

To study whether HFNC are noisier than bubble CPAP (BCPAP) for preterm infants.

An observational study of preterm infants receiving HFNC or BCPAP. Noise levels within the external auditory meatus (EAM) were measured using a microphone probe tube connected to a calibrated digital dosimeter. Noise was measured across a range of frequencies and reported as decibels A-weighted (dBA).

A total of 21 HFNC and 13 BCPAP noise measurements were performed in 21 infants. HFNC gas flows were 2-5 L/min, and BCPAP gas flows were 6-10 L/min with set pressures of 5-7 cm of water. There was no evidence of a difference in average noise levels measured at the EAM: mean difference (95% CI) of -1.6 (-4.0 to 0.9) dBA for HFNC compared to BCPAP. At low frequency (500 Hz), HFNC was mean (95% CI) 3.0 (0.3 to 5.7) dBA quieter than BCPAP. Noise increased with increasing BCPAP gas flow (p=0.007), but not with increasing set pressure. There was a trend to noise increasing with increasing HFNC gas flows.
topic: Interpretation of mean difference, 95% confidence intervals, and p-values in reporting device noise comparisons.
question: Which conclusion is most accurately supported by the reported statistics comparing HFNC and BCPAP noise levels?

choices.A: The overall mean noise reduction of 1.6 dBA for HFNC is statistically significant.
choices.B: The 3.0 dBA lower noise at 500 Hz for HFNC is statistically significant.
choices.C: The non-significant trend of HFNC noise rising with flow confirms noise invariance across HFNC settings.
choices.D: The p=0.007 value indicates no relationship between BCPAP flow rate and noise levels.

explanation: Only the low-frequency difference (3.0 dBA; 95% CI: 0.3 to 5.7) excludes zero, indicating a statistically significant reduction by HFNC at 500 Hz.

context:
To provide equality of cancer care to rural patients, Townsville Cancer Centre administers intensive chemotherapy regimens to rural patients with node-positive breast and metastatic colorectal cancers at the same doses as urban patients. Side-effects were usually managed by rural general practitioners locally.AIM: The aim is to determine the safety of this practice by comparing the profile of serious adverse events and dose intensities between urban and rural patients at the Townsville Cancer Centre.

A retrospective audit was conducted in patients with metastatic colorectal and node-positive breast cancers during a 24-month period. Fisher's exact test was used for analysis. Rurality was determined as per rural, remote and metropolitan classification.

Of the 121 patients included, 70 and 51 patients had breast and colon cancers respectively. The urban versus rural patient split among all patients, breast and colorectal cancer subgroups was 68 versus 53, 43 versus 27 and 25 versus 26 respectively. A total of 421 cycles was given with dose intensity of>95% for breast cancer in both groups (P>0.05). Rate of febrile neutropenia was 9.3% versus 7.4% (P = 0.56). For XELOX, rate of diarrhoea was 20% versus 19% (P = 0.66) and rate of vomiting was 20% versus 11% (P = 0.11). Only two patients were transferred to Townsville for admission. No toxic death occurred in either group.
topic: Assessment and comparison of XELOX regimen–related vomiting rates with P‑value interpretation
question: With XELOX-induced vomiting observed in 20% of urban versus 11% of rural patients yielding a P value of 0.11, which inference best reflects both the statistical result and its implications for future research?

choices.A: The difference is not statistically significant at the 0.05 level, and no further investigation is needed since risk is equivalent.
choices.B: A P value above 0.05 confirms there is definitively no clinically meaningful difference in vomiting risk.
choices.C: Although not statistically significant, the difference suggests a possible effect that may warrant larger studies to rule out a type II error.
choices.D: The P value of 0.11 indicates an 11% chance that the null hypothesis is true.

explanation: A P value >0.05 does not prove equivalence; it merely fails to reject the null, and a trend may reflect insufficient power, so further study could be needed.

context:
A tonsillectomy audit was carried out and compared with other studies, to emphasize the role of antibiotics.

This study was carried out at North West Armed Forces Hospital, Tabuk, Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, during the year January 1999 through to December 1999. This is a retrospective study of patients who had tonsillectomy with or with adenoidectomy, the topics audited included indication for surgery, grade of surgeon, method of surgery, length of hospital stay, complications and the use of postoperative antibiotics.

A total of 185 patients underwent tonsillectomy with or without adenoidectomy. The patients age ranged between 2 years to 53 years and the majority were children. In our audit we found no difference with regard to grade of surgeons, method of hemostasis in the outcome of surgery. Moreover, postoperative antibiotics had no role in pain control, postoperative fever, secondary hemorrhage or reduction in hospital stay. The administration of analgesics on the basis of, as required, had poor pain control.
topic: The effect of postoperative antibiotics on pain control, fever, secondary hemorrhage, and hospital stay
question: In a retrospective audit of 185 tonsillectomy patients showing no apparent benefit from postoperative antibiotics, which analytical method would most directly address selection bias from non-random antibiotic assignment?

choices.A: Stratified subgroup analysis by surgeon grade
choices.B: Propensity score matching of antibiotic and non-antibiotic groups
choices.C: Expansion of sample size to include multiple centers
choices.D: Adjustment for age and sex in a univariate model

explanation: Propensity score matching balances measured covariates between groups, directly mitigating selection bias in observational studies.

context:
Polio eradication is now feasible after removal of Nigeria from the list of endemic countries and global reduction of cases of wild polio virus in 2015 by more than 80%. However, all countries must remain focused to achieve eradication. In August 2015, the Catholic bishops in Kenya called for boycott of a polio vaccination campaign citing safety concerns with the polio vaccine. We conducted a survey to establish if the coverage was affected by the boycott.

A cross sectional survey was conducted in all the 32 counties that participated in the campaign. A total of 90,157 children and 37,732 parents/guardians were sampled to determine the vaccination coverage and reasons for missed vaccination.

The national vaccination coverage was 93% compared to 94% in the November 2014 campaign. The proportion of parents/guardians that belonged to Catholic Church was 31% compared to 7% of the children who were missed. Reasons for missed vaccination included house not being visited (44%), children not being at home at time of visit (38%), refusal by parents (12%), children being as leep (1%), and various other reasons (5%). Compared to the November 2014 campaign, the proportion of children who were not vaccinated due to parent's refusal significantly increased from 6% to 12% in August 2015.
topic: Propose strategies to address parental safety concerns and refusal in future polio campaigns, drawing from health communication theory.
question: Considering the doubled parental refusal rate driven by safety concerns, which intervention rooted in the Health Belief Model would most effectively reduce refusals in future polio campaigns?

choices.A: Convene small‐group forums led by trusted Catholic community leaders that communicate vaccine safety and benefits (lowering perceived barriers, raising perceived benefits), paired with personalized reminder home visits as cues to action.
choices.B: Air nationwide fear‐based advertisements highlighting the severe paralysis caused by polio to increase perceived susceptibility and severity.
